categories.summary:
# Discord Chat Analysis

## 1. Summary
The chat segment contains a brief technical discussion about hosting VRM files for avatars. Roustan explains that they use Arweave (app.ardrive.io) for decentralized hosting of avatar files, mentioning it costs approximately $0.10-$0.50 per avatar depending on file size. They also reference creating a tutorial for hosting on Google APIs (Web2) for users who don't fully understand decentralization. Additionally, there's a brief discussion about intellectual property rights related to RTFKT clones, with Roustan clarifying that modified clones can be sold as long as they don't contain Nike or RTFKT logos and are properly labeled with the clone number.

## 2. FAQ
Q: How do you arrange the VRM file share in practice? Does it cost you money? (asked by Fibelius) A: I use Arweave https://app.ardrive.io I put down $10 and each avatar probably costs me like .10 - .50 cents depending on file size. I also made a tutorial for hosting them on web2 google apis for peeps that don't fully understand decentralization. (answered by ğ•½ğ–”ğ–šğ–˜ğ–™ğ–†ğ–“)

Helper: ğ•½ğ–”ğ–šğ–˜ğ–™ğ–†ğ–“ | Helpee: Fibelius | Context: Concerns about RTFKT IPR policy and Nike lawyers regarding modified clones | Resolution: Clarified that modified clones can be sold if they don't contain Nike/RTFKT logos and are properly labeled with clone numbers

## 4. Action Items
Technical: Use Arweave for decentralized VRM file hosting | Description: Cost-effective solution at $0.10-$0.50 per avatar | Mentioned By: ğ•½ğ–”ğ–šğ–˜ğ–™ğ–†ğ–“
Documentation: Follow YouTube tutorial for Web2 hosting alternatives | Description: Guide for users who don't understand decentralization | Mentioned By: ğ•½ğ–”ğ–šğ–˜ğ–™ğ–†ğ–“
Technical: Label modified clones properly | Description: Include clone number and label as "modified clone #1234" | Mentioned By: ğ•½ğ–”ğ–šğ–˜ğ–™ğ–†ğ–“

The chat segment is brief and covers two main topics. First, a user inquired about a hyperlink (.hyp) for avatar equipment functionality, to which another user responded with a Discord message link and suggested searching for "Avatar Station" for more information. Second, a user announced the launch of an open-source 3D assets website (opensource3dassets.com), sharing both the website link and a related tweet, while requesting feedback on the platform.
